Don't get me wrong I'm a big fan of JUnit and unit testing but...

...I do=
 regularly have problems using components, which would not have
occurred if=
 there had been clearly stated pre-conditions (admittedly these
components =
don't usually come with associated unit tests).
Are a collection of unit te=
sts a clear statement of the contract? I'm not
convinced. I do agree that b=
y rigourously using TFD you will end up with
classes/methods with sweet sme=
lling contracts. However if we consider the
airline metaphor which is often=
 used for DBC: when I'm booking a ticket
with an airline I like to know the=
 conditions which are attached - I don't
merely  want a list of previous pa=
ssengers and how they got on.

Steven Hale, wm-data

> >From: steven.hal=
e@...
> >
> >Interesting to see that John Goodsen (private method threa=
d) is using
> >Design By Contract in conjunction with unit testing and JUni=
t. Is
anybody
> >else is doing this and how they are implementing DBC (iCon=
tract? JASS?
or
> >merely at a documentation level?)
>
>JBR
>
>Test-Driven =
Development drives a programmer towards DBC on a test-by-test
>basis. As a =
result, although I don't use DBC tools, I believe I'm doing
DBC
>
>by simpl=
y writing the tests first. In a way, JUnit is my DBC tool.
>
>From: steven.=
hale@...
>
>I can see your point from a component manufacturer's point =
of view - I can
>test that I can fullfil my contract using JUnit.
>
>From a=
 component user view point I'd still like to see a concise
>description of =
the prerequisites without having to dig into the component
>code or even th=
e unit testing code...
>... though I realise I'm in danger of reopening the=
 javadoc v unit test
>discussion :-)

Indeed. Not only that, as a component=
 user, I find that Javadoc is
sufficient to my purpose most of the time. It=
 is rare that I need the level

of detail that a class' contract gives me. =
When I do need it, I want it in
a
formal notation, since natural languages =
are ambiguous. At that point, Java

code is the preferred formal notation, =
since Java is the language I program

in the most. I'll accept Smalltalk an=
d muddle through with Ruby. Any way
you
slice it, I wanna see code. The bes=
t code is self-verifying executing code.

Sounds like a JUnit test. :)
